responses.content:
Well, it's a very interesting question, a very, very appropriate question at this time. And as I say, we have had as I indicated, we started this process almost 9 months ago because we were seeing demand that is quite strong. We started the process of thinking about how we best ensure very, very good use of our supply chain capacity. We went through this process rigorously scrubbing our backlog.

Our entire backlog virtually follows a key set of terms we mentioned before, which is non-cancelable for any of our customers who booked us, and they still apply, more so than ever. So double bookings from our point of view are not and they've never been an issue. As we stretch our lead times, we are seeing customers book for delivery dates that are further out, which makes sense.

This allows us to match customer consumption closely against what we supply. We feel pretty good that we have a reasonable process in place that ensures our customers get the products when they need them. Our revenue year-on-year in Q1 was up 17%, and our bookings were up 63%, proving strong demand. We are virtually 90% booked for 2021, reflecting real and sustainable demand.

responses.topic: Growth in Wireless and Supply Chain Capacity
responses.content: Yes, we have done a decent job. Over the last 6 months, and we continue to do so, we've been able to meet the critical needs of all our customers. Our in-house manufacturing capabilities have been expanded to handle the seasonal upcycle in the back half of the wireless business. This ensures that we have the capacity to drive higher revenues in the July and October quarters, assuming our backlog supports that profile.

responses.topic: Wireless Growth and C-Band Spectrum Auctions
responses.content: On the latter part, yes, it is an outer year. This thing doesn't get implemented so fast. And on the formal part of your question, I can't answer that, I'm sorry. For obvious reasons, it's too early. We will tell you about it when the time is appropriate. Thank you.

Another way to answer that question, John, is when do you see lead time reduce or normalize. Right now, I don't know the answer to that. We have extended lead times over the past several months and continue to do so. We are getting bookings from customers, and when those bookings start to disappear, that's when demand may start to decline. We have not reached that point yet.

responses.topic: Software Bookings and Revenue Growth Confidence
responses.content: Yes. As I indicated in my prepared remarks on some of the key metrics we go by, we feel very, very good about those two. We are focusing on core customers and uplifting capacity, entitlements, and products across our portfolio. On non-core areas, we see a manageable level of attrition, which is offset by improvement in the core, allowing us to reach stabilization around mid-single digits consistently. Our enterprise customers continue to consume our products, especially in this pandemic environment.

Tim, bookings started ramping up as early as Q3, shot up in Q4, and started declining in late Q4 and Q1. Q1 bookings showed an 80% year-on-year improvement, netting out a decline in wireless bookings as expected seasonally. The revenue reflects this, with declining wireless bookings offset by strong performance in other segments.

Yes, great question. People need our products across all our end markets. Whether it's broadband, networking, or cloud scaling, our customers require our products to launch more broadband and improve their networks. They are willing to book products 6 to 8 months out to reserve capacity, indicating strong and mission-critical demand. This is not a panic mode but a structured and reasonable process reflecting real underlying demand.

In Q1, our gross margins were up by 30 basis points year-over-year, largely due to wireless. For Q2, we will have fewer wireless revenues in the margin mix, so you should look back at Q4 to model Q2 margins. As the year progresses, margins will reflect more normal seasonality in wireless for the second half.
